Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Introductory Computer Science Projects via Real-TimeWeb Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project creates an educational software infrastructure by broadening the support for the successful BusTracker.edu API to support computer programming projects that use real-time Web-based data to better engage and better train introductory computer science students. Examples of real-time data accessible over the Web include stock values, traffic information, weather, public transit, flight information, inventory overviews, and many others. The infrastructure ensures the requisite data availability, integrity, and accessibility, as well as automates grading techniques.

By bringing real-world, real-time data of intrinsic interest to students in introductory classes, more students are expected to be recruited into and retained in the computer science major. The new programming projects also provide an opportunity to introduce students earlier to advanced concepts such as distributed computing and cyber-physical systems, thereby better preparing them to meet the emerging challenges of the IT workplace.

In addition to the infrastructure, the project will produce a set of programming assignments using the infrastructure suitable for CS 1 and CS 2 courses. Evaluation encompasses both the new system, as well as the effect of its use on student learning outcomes and on retention. The infrastructure will be available through a dedicated website and a number of workshops will assist faculty in learning to use the new system in their courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major issue that plagues computer science educational programs is the inability to properly motivate and retain a diverse group of learners. One of the problems exacerbating this state of affairs is the way in which projects in introductory classes are designed and executed. Specificially, these projects suffer from being decontextualized and dealing with abstract theories and concepts.

The goal of our project has been to address this problem by restructuring introductory programming projects to incorporate data sources that students experience as end-users of computing. For example, this project makes it possible to assign introductory programming projects that use data from sources including weather forecasts, stock trading reports, earthquakes, local shopping, etc. This project solves the technical challenges of using these unwieldly real-live data sources in introductory programming projects in which students have had limited exposure to and experience with computing technologies.

The software infrastructure developed in this project has been used as an educational intervention in several introductory computing classes taught at Virginia Tech and the University of Delaware. The evaluation of this intervention has been overall positive, validating the original hypothesis posed by this project. These artificats will continue to be used in these classes after the project is over.

Having conducted this research, we have gained a more thorough understanding of the actual positive impact that contextualizing introductory programming projects can have on students' engagement and retention. We have disseminated the software artifacts to our peers in other institutions through two formal workshops held at the premiere conference of computing educators (SIGCSE). The research produced by this project also recieved an award at a student research competition held at SIGCSE. All the materials and software developed for the project are publicly available for download and experimentation at http://think.cs.vt.edu/wiki/

As reported by industry, the US is experiencing a shortage of qualified STEM professionals. To increase the production of qualified computing specialists, computing educators can improve recruitment and retention rates. The activities carried out under the aegis of this project have the potential to play an important role in reaching these lofty objectives.
